column1: Pereira (Spanish pronunciation: [peˈɾejɾa]) is the capital city of the Colombian department of Risaralda. It is located in the foothills of the Andes in a coffee-producing area of Colombia officially known as the "Coffee Axis". Pereira
column2: alongside the rest of the Coffee Axis
column3: form part of UNESCO World Heritage Site known as the "Coffee Cultural Landscape of Colombia". It is the most populated city in the Coffee Axis and the second-most populated city in the Paisa region
column4: after Medellín. Pereira is also part of the Central West Metropolitan Area
column5: which has 709
column6: 322 residents and is composed of Pereira and the neighboring cities of Dosquebradas and La Virginia.As the capital of the department of Risaralda
column7: Pereira houses the headquarters of the Government of Risaralda
column9: the Departmental Court
column10: the Metropolitan Area Authority and the Attorney General. It also serves as the headquarters for numerous public companies and institutions of the Colombian state. Being in the center of the Golden Triangle (which consists of the cities of Bogotá
column13: Pereira has become especially important in the fields of trade and commerce.

column1: The history of the city goes back to the pre-Columbian era
column2: in which the current city area was inhabited by the Quimbaya and Pijao cultures
column3: widely recognized for their goldsmiths. In this region
column4: Marshal Jorge Robledo founded the city of Cartago (Carthage) on August 9
column6: but due to the siege of the pijaos or reasons of economic expediency this city was moved in 1691 to the site that currently occupies the north end of the Valley of the Cauca
column7: towards the banks of the La Vieja river. The original site became jungle again and buried the remains of civilization. On the few ruins of the Spanish population
column8: crossed by the route that led from Valle del Cauca to Medellín
column9: through Manizales
column10: a group of 20 Antioqueno families had already built their homes when a handful of Vallecaucanos appeared to find the population of Carthage La Vieja
column11: today Pereira. Although the formal foundation came from the Caucano group
column12: the emergence of Pereira was another chapter of the Antioqueno colonization
column13: and the contribution of other social groups such as the Caucano was in its beginning relatively scarce.

column2: with the ideal of reviving this city
column3: which until then was a jungle area
column6: the presbyter Remigio Antonio Cañarte and Jesús María Ormaza Niño
column8: returned to the ruins of ancient Carthage
column9: where they established a few huts that were blessed on August 30 of the same year. For 6 years the settlement was called Carthage
column10: but in 1869 it was renamed Villa de Pereira
column11: in honor of the doctor Francisco Pereira Martínez
column12: who in 1816 took refuge in the area
column13: along with his brother Manuel Pereira
column14: after the defeat of the patriotic hosts of Simón Bolívar in the battle of Cachirí.

column1: From 1870 and especially as a result of the civil wars of 1876 and 1885
column2: the region received a new wave of immigrants from Antioquia. The settler group of 1863 and following years had been formed by forest reclaimers who only aspired to have a single plot of land
column3: while the second group was made up of men of greater ambition and greater entrepreneurial capacity. Some of them were linked to Antioquian capitalists who financed their activities
column4: which involved leveling mountains and starting cattle ranches using peonadas and heavy capital investments. The arrival in the city of a group of merchants and professionals at the end of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th introduced education as a new reason for social differentiation. A new elite group emerged that became a leader of the economic
column5: civic
column6: and political activities of the city.

column1: Pereira was the city where the last execution in Colombia took place. David López
column3: was indicted for the murder of Ricardo Torres on November 30
column4: 1888. Lopez unsuccessfully exhausted all appeals to spare his life; he was executed in Pereira on July 26
column6: after telling the firing squad to shoot directly at his heart.

column2: settlers from Antioquia moved to Pereira for its economically strategic location
column3: fertile soil
column4: and good weather. The settlers grew large quantities of high-quality coffee in the mineral-rich
column5: volcanic Andean soil. Other produce included sugarcane and cattle. Settlers also came from cities such as Valle del Cauca and Bogotá. In the 1950s
column6: during a period of bipartisan political struggle in the country
column7: Pereira became a refuge for thousands of Colombians
column8: quadrupling its population and creating a national melting pot that changed its community forever. In recent years
column9: the city has achieved an urban identity and a significant growth in its cultural development. Social integration and higher levels of education are providing the city sustained economic and cultural growth.

column1: Pereira is currently undergoing a transitional phase

column1: A bus system which has almost 50 routes in the city is soon to be replaced. It has a cost of $2.000 which is paid directly to the driver in cash.

Part of the new transit development plan is to build 3 new cable car lines across the city. It was announced that final routes would be from Industrial Park (Parque industrial) to the airport
column2: Villa Santana to the UTP University
